remixlab.proscene

Class Quaternion

  • java.lang.Object
    • remixlab.proscene.Quaternion
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    processing.core.PConstants

    public class Quaternion
extends java.lang.Object
implements processing.core.PConstants
    A 4 element unit quaternion represented by single precision floating point x,y,z,w coordinates.

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      float w
      The w coordinate which corresponds to the scalar part of the Quaternion.
      float x
      The x coordinate, i.e., the x coordinate of the vector part of the Quaternion.
      float y
      The y coordinate, i.e., the y coordinate of the vector part of the Quaternion.
      float z
      The z coordinate, i.e., the z coordinate of the vector part of the Quaternion.

        y - the y coordinate

      • dotProduct

        public final float dotProduct(Quaternion b)
        Returns the "dot" product of this Quaternion and b:

        this.x * b.x + this.y * b.y + this.z * b.z + this.w * b.w

        Parameters:
        b - the Quaternion

      • dotProduct

        public static final float dotProduct(Quaternion a,
               Quaternion b)
        Returns the "dot" product of a and b:

        a.x * b.x + a.y * b.y + a.z * b.z + a.w * b.w

        Parameters:
        a - the first Quaternion
        b - the second Quaternion

      • multiplyInverse

        public final void multiplyInverse(Quaternion q1)
        Multiplies this Quaternion by the inverse of Quaternion q1 and places the value into this Quaternion (i.e., this = this * q^-1). The value of the argument Quaternion is preserved.
        Parameters:
        q1 - the other Quaternion

      • multiplyInverse

        public static final Quaternion multiplyInverse(Quaternion q1,
                         Quaternion q2)
        Returns the product of Quaternion q1 by the inverse of Quaternion q2 (i.e., q1 * q2^-1). The value of both argument quaternions is preserved.
        Parameters:
        q1 - the first Quaternion
        q2 - the second Quaternion

      • inverse

        public final Quaternion inverse()
        Returns the inverse Quaternion (inverse rotation).

        The result has a negated axis() direction and the same angle().

        A composition of a Quaternion and its inverse() results in an identity function. Use invert() to actually modify the Quaternion.

        See Also:
        invert()

      • invert

        public final void invert()
        Sets the value of this Quaternion to the inverse of itself.
        See Also:

        Parameters:

      • fromAxisAngle

        public void fromAxisAngle(processing.core.PVector axis,
                 float angle)
        Sets the Quaternion as a rotation of axis and angle (in radians).

        The axis does not need to be normalized. A null axis will result in an identity Quaternion.

        Parameters:
        axis - the PVector representing the axis
        angle - the angle in radians

                 float pitch,
                 float yaw)
        Same as fromEulerAngles(float, float, float).

      • fromEulerAngles

        public void fromEulerAngles(processing.core.PVector angles)
        Convenience function that simply calls fromEulerAngles(angles.x, angles.y, angles.z).
        See Also:
        fromEulerAngles(float, float, float), eulerAngles()

      • fromEulerAngles

        public void fromEulerAngles(float roll,
                   float pitch,
                   float yaw)
        Converts Euler rotation angles roll, pitch and yaw, respectively defined to the x, y and z axes, to this Quaternion. In the convention used here these angles represent a composition of extrinsic rotations (rotations about the reference frame axes), which is also known as taitBryanAngles() (See http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Euler_angles and http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tait-Bryan_angles). eulerAngles() performs the inverse operation.

        Each rotation angle is converted to an axis-angle pair, with the axis corresponding to one of the Euclidean axes. The axis-angle pairs are converted to quaternions and multiplied together. The order of the rotations is: y->z->x which follows the convention found here: http://www.euclideanspace.com/maths/geometry/rotations/euler/index.htm.

        See Also:
        eulerAngles()

      • taitBryanAngles

        public processing.core.PVector taitBryanAngles()
        Same as eulerAngles().

      • eulerAngles

        public processing.core.PVector eulerAngles()
        Converts this Quaternion to Euler rotation angles roll, pitch and yaw in radians. fromEulerAngles(float, float, float) performs the inverse operation. The code was adapted from: http://www.euclideanspace.com/maths/geometry /rotations/conversions/quaternionToEuler/index.htm.

        Attention: This method assumes that this Quaternion is normalized.

        Returns:
        the PVector holding the roll (x coordinate of the vector), pitch (y coordinate of the vector) and yaw angles (z coordinate of the vector). Note: The order of the rotations that would produce this Quaternion (i.e., as with fromEulerAngles(roll, pitch, yaw)) is: y->z->x.
        See Also:
        fromEulerAngles(float, float, float)

      • fromTo

        public void fromTo(processing.core.PVector from,
          processing.core.PVector to)
        Sets the Quaternion as a rotation from the from direction to the to direction.

        Attention: this rotation is not uniquely defined. The selected axis is usually orthogonal to from and to, minimizing the rotation angle. This method is robust and can handle small or almost identical vectors.

        See Also:
        fromAxisAngle(PVector, float)

      • fromRotationMatrix

        public final void fromRotationMatrix(float[][] m)
        Set the Quaternion from a (supposedly correct) 3x3 rotation matrix.

        The matrix is expressed in European format: its three columns are the images by the rotation of the three vectors of an orthogonal basis.

        fromRotatedBasis(PVector, PVector, PVector) sets a Quaternion from the three axis of a rotated frame. It actually fills the three columns of a matrix with these rotated basis vectors and calls this method.

        Parameters:
        m - the 3*3 matrix of float values

      • fromMatrix

        public final void fromMatrix(processing.core.PMatrix3D pM)
        Set the Quaternion from a (supposedly correct) 3x3 rotation matrix given in the upper left 3x3 sub-matrix of the PMatrix3D.
        See Also:
        fromRotationMatrix(float[][])

      • fromRotatedBasis

        public final void fromRotatedBasis(processing.core.PVector X,
                    processing.core.PVector Y,
                    processing.core.PVector Z)
        Sets the Quaternion from the three rotated vectors of an orthogonal basis.

        The three vectors do not have to be normalized but must be orthogonal and direct (i,e., X^Y=k*Z, with k>0).

        Parameters:
        X - the first PVector
        Y - the second PVector
        Z - the third PVector
        See Also:
        fromRotationMatrix(float[][]), Quaternion(PVector, PVector)

      • axis

        public final processing.core.PVector axis()
        Returns the normalized axis direction of the rotation represented by the Quaternion.

        The result is null for an identity Quaternion.

        See Also:
        angle()

      • angle

        public final float angle()
        Returns the angle (in radians) of the rotation represented by the Quaternion.

        This value is always in the range [0-pi]. Larger rotational angles are obtained by inverting the axis() direction.

        See Also:
        axis()

      • rotationMatrix

        public final float[][] rotationMatrix()
        Returns the 3x3 rotation matrix associated with the Quaternion.

        Attention: The method returns the European mathematical representation of the rotation matrix.

        See Also:
        inverseRotationMatrix()

      • matrix

        public final processing.core.PMatrix3D matrix()
        Returns the PMatrix3D (processing matrix) which represents the rotation matrix associated with the Quaternion.
        See Also:
        rotationMatrix()

      • inverseMatrix

        public final processing.core.PMatrix3D inverseMatrix()
        Returns the associated inverse rotation processing PMatrix3D. This is simply matrix() of the inverse().

        Attention: The result is only valid until the next call to inverseMatrix(). Use it immediately (as in applyMatrix(q.inverseMatrix())).

      • inverseRotationMatrix

        public final float[][] inverseRotationMatrix()
        Returns the 3x3 inverse rotation matrix associated with the Quaternion.

        Attention: This is the classical mathematical rotation matrix.

      • log

        public final Quaternion log()
        Returns the logarithm of the Quaternion.
        See Also:
        exp()

      • exp

        public final Quaternion exp()
        Returns the exponential of the Quaternion.
        See Also:
        log()

      • randomQuaternion

        public static final Quaternion randomQuaternion()
        Returns a random unit Quaternion.

        You can create a randomly directed unit vector using:

        PVector randomDir = new PVector(1.0f, 0.0f, 0.0f);
        randomDir = Quaternion.multiply(Quaternion.randomQuaternion(), randomDir);

      • slerp

        public static final Quaternion slerp(Quaternion a,
               Quaternion b,
               float t)
        Wrapper function that simply calls slerp(a, b, t, true).

        See slerp(Quaternion, Quaternion, float, boolean) for details.

      • slerp

        public static final Quaternion slerp(Quaternion a,
               Quaternion b,
               float t,
               boolean allowFlip)
        Returns the slerp interpolation of quaternions a and b, at time t.

        t should range in [0,1]. Result is a when t=0 and b when t=1.

        When allowFlip is true (default) the slerp interpolation will always use the "shortest path" between the quaternions' orientations, by "flipping" the source Quaternion if needed (see negate()).

        Parameters:
        a - the first Quaternion
        b - the second Quaternion
        t - the t interpolation parameter
        allowFlip - tells whether or not the interpolation allows axis flip

      • squad

        public static final Quaternion squad(Quaternion a,
               Quaternion tgA,
               Quaternion tgB,
               Quaternion b,
               float t)
        Returns the slerp interpolation of the two quaternions a and b, at time t, using tangents tgA and tgB.

        The resulting Quaternion is "between" a and b (result is a when t=0 and b for t=1).

        Use squadTangent(Quaternion, Quaternion, Quaternion) to define the Quaternion tangents tgA and tgB.

        Parameters:
        a - the first Quaternion
        tgA - the first tangent Quaternion
        tgB - the second tangent Quaternion
        b - the second Quaternion
        t - the t interpolation parameter

      • lnDif

        public static final Quaternion lnDif(Quaternion a,
               Quaternion b)
        Simply returns log(a. inverse() * b).

        Useful for squadTangent(Quaternion, Quaternion, Quaternion).

        Parameters:
        a - the first Quaternion
        b - the second Quaternion

      • squadTangent

        public static final Quaternion squadTangent(Quaternion before,
                      Quaternion center,
                      Quaternion after)
        Returns a tangent Quaternion for center, defined by before and after quaternions.
        Parameters:
        before - the first Quaternion
        center - the second Quaternion
        after - the third Quaternion

      • squaredNorm

        public static float squaredNorm(Quaternion q)
        Utility function that returns the squared norm of the Quaternion.
